thread.title: Gorsuch Distances Himself From Trump's Comments On The Judiciary
thread.title_full: Gorsuch Distances Himself From Trump's Comments On The Judiciary

title: Gorsuch Distances Himself From Trump's Comments On The Judiciary

organizations.name: saying yemen raid wasn’t a success 9th circuit court delays decision on trump’s travel
major cities chiefs association winter conference

text:
Judge Neil Gorsuch is President Donald Trump’s Supreme Court nominee, but that does not mean the jurist will back the president on everything Trump says.
During a private meeting Wednesday with Sen. Richard Blumenthal, D-Conn., Gorsuch lamented Trump’s way of attacking judges with whom he disagrees.
“I told him how abhorrent Donald Trump’s invective and insults are towards the judiciary. And he said to me that he found them ‘disheartening’ and ‘demoralizing’ – his words,” Blumenthal said later.
  More New Jobs As Trump Announces $7 Billion Investment By Intel White House Calls On McCain To Apologize For Saying Yemen Raid Wasn’t A Success 9th Circuit Court Delays Decision On Trump’s Travel Ban Gorsuch “stated very emotionally and strongly his belief in his fellow judges’ integrity and the principle of judicial independence,” he added.
Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch said he finds Trump's attack on the judicial branch "disheartening." https://t.co/iIvMCe7KND 
— USA TODAY (@USATODAY) February 8, 2017 

“I believe he has an obligation to make his views known more explicit and unequivocally to the American people,” Blumenthal later said.
 
Ron Bonjean , a member of the transition team assisting Gorsuch in the confirmation process, said the words “disheartening” and “demoralizing” were used by Gorsuch in the context of Trump’s tweet Saturday that attacked a judge who put a hold on Trump’s executive order regarding immigration.
The opinion of this so-called judge, which essentially takes law-enforcement away from our country, is ridiculous and will be overturned!
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 4, 2017 

Trump followed that with another volley on Monday.
Because the ban was lifted by a judge, many very bad and dangerous people may be pouring into our country. A terrible decision
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 4, 2017 

  Cruz Explodes At Democrats After Warren’s Tirade Against Sessions After Miraculous Super Bowl Win, Patriots Player Says He’ll Skip White House Visit Republican Congressman Pushes To Abolish Department Of Education Those were not the only recent comments Trump has made questioning the judiciary.
“If you were a good student in high school or a bad student in high school, you can understand this and it’s really incredible to me that we have a court case that’s going on so long,” Trump said Wednesday at the Major Cities Chiefs Association Winter Conference in Washington, referring to his right to issue the controversial executive order.
“But courts seem to be so political and it would be so great for our justice system if they would be able to read a statement and do what’s right,” Trump added. “Right now, we are at risk because of what happened.”
White House press secretary Sean Spicer said Trump is merely sharing his frustration with the process.
“He respects the judiciary,” Spicer said. “It’s hard for him and for a lot of people to understand how something so clear in the law can be so misinterpreted.”
What do you think?
